title: Taxman gets new US-style powers to raid tens of thousands of personal bank accounts to recover debts
text:
Print 
HMRC says 17,000 'non-compliant individuals and businesses are likely to be affected by this measure each year' despite new safeguards to allay concerns 
Tens of thousands of people will have their personal bank accounts raided by inspectors chasing unpaid tax bills due to a change in the law, despite new safeguards introduced after widespread concern. 
Inspectors from HM Revenue and Customs are to get controversial new American-style powers to recover tax directly from people’s bank accounts 
The powers which were set out in documents published alongside this week’s Budget - extend to taking cash directly from tax shelters like individual savings accounts. 
• Osborne: living wage will leave Brits better off despite welfare cuts 
Small firms groups savaged the plans, with one organisation saying that “essentially it allows HMRC to play both judge and jury with little or no external oversight”. 
HMRC forecasts say that 17,000 “non-compliant individuals and businesses are likely to be affected by this measure each year”. 
The law change will cost HMRC £800,000 to implement but is likely to raise hundreds of millions of pounds. 
The measure will raise a total of £470million between now and 2020, starting at £20million this year, rising to £110million, £130million, £115million and £95million in the following years. 
Details of the change which will be formally debated by MPs and peers in the Summer Finance Bill - are contained in the documents published alongside Wednesday’s Budget. 
They say: “This Government will introduce legislation to modernise and strengthen HMRC’s power to recover tax and tax credit debts directly from debtors’ bank and building society accounts, including fund held in cash ISAs.” 
The Treasury has agreed to implement safeguards, which will give people the right to appeal in the county courts and “a face to face visit to every debtor before they are considered for debt recovery through this measure”. 
HMRC said that it would only “take action against debtors who owe over £1,000 of tax or tax credits debt”. 
It said that it would “always leave a minimum aggregate of £5,000 across debtors accounts and will only put a hold on the funds in the affected account up to the value of the debt”. 
In cases where the debt is held on a joint account HMRC “is introducing safeguards so that only a pro-rata proportion of the balance in a joint account will be affected”. 
HMRC will not be allowed to target accounts which are hold by parents on behalf of their children. 
Small business groups warned that they were “very concerned about the implications of these proposals”. 
• Shareholders facing £7bn raid on income from dividends 
• Insurers warn tax grab could lead to higher prices 
John Allan, national chairman at the Federation of Small Businesses, said: “We're sceptical the tax risk and number of cases warrant giving HMRC such far reaching and comprehensive powers. 
“It moves the UK towards a US system, where the IRS has considerable reach. 
“We need an open debate about whether citizens are comfortable with such powers being in the hands of the UK tax authorities. 
“The proposals come alongside a broad raft of new data collection measures allowing HMRC ever more power to pry directly into the affairs of citizens most of whom are trying to do the right thing. 
“HMRC already has a clear legal route to making debtors pay, but the system requires HMRC to prove money is owed in court before being able to take it. 
“The proposed new powers permit HMRC to take the money on its own say-so. Essentially it allows HMRC to play both judge and jury with little or no external oversight. 
“In our view this undermines due process without independent, judicial oversight and is a step too far.” 
Paul Aplin, chairman of the tax faculty at the Institute of Chartered Accountants of England and Wales, added: “Ministers have given assurances that the power would be subject to the toughest scrutiny and oversight possible and we will be looking closely at the draft legislation when it is published next week to ensure that the safeguards are clearly and fully set out.”
